formulas.label: <<FORMULA_0066>>
formulas.high_level_explanation: This optimization defines a variant of low-rank optimal transport that seeks factors Q* and R* minimizing the transport cost given by the Frobenius inner product between the cost matrix C and the low-rank coupling Q diag(1/g) R^T. The factors Q and R parameterize a rank-r coupling matrix, with g fixed to be uniform so each rank component carries equal weight. The constraints restrict Q and R to feasibility sets tied to prescribed marginals, while g = (1/r)1_r enforces uniform intermediate weights. This problem targets low-rank structure that can be used for hierarchical refinement and co-clustering.

notations.\\mathbf{Q}^\\star: Optimal left low-rank factor (minimizer of the problem)
notations.\\mathbf{R}^\\star: Optimal right low-rank factor (minimizer of the problem)
notations.\\mathbf{Q}: Left factor in the low-rank coupling parameterization
notations.\\mathbf{R}: Right factor in the low-rank coupling parameterization
notations.\\mathbf{C}: Cost matrix of the optimal transport problem
notations.r: Rank parameter (number of components/columns in the low-rank factors)

formulas.label: <<FORMULA_0303>>
formulas.high_level_explanation: The identity rewrites the Frobenius inner product between the cost matrix C and a matrix P as a trace and shows it is invariant under a simultaneous right-multiplication by the same permutation/orthogonal matrix. It inserts the identity \tilde{\mb{P}}^{-1}\tilde{\mb{P}} inside the trace and uses cyclic invariance of the trace, together with \tilde{\mb{P}}^{-1} = \tilde{\mb{P}}^\top, to obtain an equivalent inner product between column-permuted versions of C and P. This establishes \langle C, P \rangle_F = \langle C\tilde{P}^\top, P\tilde{P}^\top \rangle_F.

notations.\\la \\mb{C}, \\mb{P} \\ra_F: Frobenius inner product between matrices \mb{C} and \mb{P}

formulas.label: <<FORMULA_0339>>
formulas.high_level_explanation: This chain of equalities shows that the Frobenius inner product between a transformed cost matrix and a factorized coupling is invariant under simultaneous permutation/orthogonal transformations. The steps use the identity ‚ü®A, B‚ü©_F = Tr(A^T B), the cyclic invariance of the trace, and the fact that permutation matrices are orthogonal so their transposes cancel inside the trace. Consequently, the objective value can be written equivalently without the permutation factors, reducing to ‚ü®C, Q^* R^{*,	op}‚ü©_F.

notations.\\mb{Q}^\\star: Optimal factor matrix in the low-rank problem (as specified in the paper).
notations.\\mb{R}^\\star: Optimal factor matrix paired with \mb{Q}^\star (as specified in the paper).
notations.\\mb{P}^\\dagger: Permutation matrix corresponding to a permutation (introduced earlier in the context).

formulas.label: <<FORMULA_0436>>
formulas.high_level_explanation: The expression defines the diameter of the co-cluster Œì_{t,q} as the diameter of the joint set formed by points in X_q^{(t)} together with their images under the current transport map T. Concretely, it computes a size measure by taking the maximum norm of the sum of two paired points (x_i, T(x_j)) and (x_k, T(x_l)) drawn from the cluster. This yields a single scalar quantifying the extent of the co-cluster in the product space induced by X and T(X).

notations.\\mathrm{diam}: Diameter operator measuring the size of a set (here in the product space of X and T(X))
notations.\\Gamma_{t,q}: The q-th co-cluster at hierarchy depth t
notations.\\mathsf{X}_q^{(t)}: The subset of X associated with co-cluster q at depth t
notations.T: Transport map sending points in X to Y (current mapping)

formulas.label: <<FORMULA_0437>>
formulas.high_level_explanation: The expression rewrites the difference in transport costs between two consecutive hierarchy levels, measured as inner products of the cost matrix with the transport couplings at steps t and t+1. It expands these costs into sums over all point pairs, weighted by indicators of their membership in co-clusters at depths t and t+1. The equalities factor and regroup terms to express the difference as a scaled sum of within-cluster costs over the current partition and its refinement.

notations.\\langle \\mathbf{C}, \\mathbf{P}^{(t)}: Total transport cost under coupling at depth t (Frobenius inner product of the cost matrix and the coupling)
notations.\\langle \\mathbf{C}, \\mathbf{P}^{(t +: Total transport cost under the refined coupling at depth t+1
notations.\\mathbf{P}^{(t)}: Transport coupling at hierarchy depth t between the full datasets
notations.\\mathbf{P}^{(t + 1)}: Transport coupling at hierarchy depth t+1 between the full datasets
notations.\\rho_t: Effective rank at depth t (rank of the implicit transport map)
notations.r_{t+1}: Rank-schedule parameter at level t+1 (refinement factor)
notations.c(\\mathbf{x}_{i}, \\mathbf{y}_{j}): Pairwise transport cost between data points \mathbf{x}_{i} and \mathbf{y}_{j}
notations.\\mathbf{x}_{i}: i-th data point in the source dataset
notations.\\mathbf{y}_{j}: j-th data point in the target dataset
notations.\\Gamma_{t,q}: q-th co-cluster (block) in the co-clustering at depth t
notations.\\Gamma_{t+1,q'}: q'-th co-cluster in the co-clustering at depth t+1 (a refinement of depth-t clusters)
notations.\\delta_{(\\mathbf{x}_{i}, \\mathbf{y}_{: Indicator equal to 1 if (\mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathbf{y}_{j}) belongs to co-cluster \Gamma_{t,q}, and 0 otherwise
Indicator equal to 1 if (\mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathbf{y}_{j}) belongs to co-cluster \Gamma_{t+1,q'}, and 0 otherwise

formulas.label: <<FORMULA_0438>>
formulas.high_level_explanation: This expression aggregates, over all co-clusters at depth t, the difference between a coarse average cost within each cluster and the total cost evaluated on its r_{t+1} refined subclusters. The quantity is normalized by n^2 and scaled by a factor denoted \rho_{t\\times1}. It represents the per-step change in the transport cost ("Monge distortion") when refining the coupling from depth t to t+1, and each inner summand is nonnegative by construction.

notations.\\rho_t: Effective rank at depth t (number of co-clusters)
notations.r_{t+1}: Rank at depth t+1 in the rank-schedule
notations.\\mathsf{X}_{q}^{(t)}: Index set of points in the q-th cluster at depth t
notations.\\mathsf{X}_{q \\rho_t + z}^{(t+1)}: Index set of points in the (q \rho_t + z)-th cluster at depth t+1
notations.\\mathbf{x}_{i}: i-th data point in the dataset X
notations.T( \\mathbf{x}_{j}): Image of the j-th point under the transport map T
notations.c: Pairwise cost function (assumed strictly convex and Lipschitz)
notations.\\Gamma_{t,q}: The q-th co-cluster at depth t

formulas.label: <<FORMULA_0441>>
formulas.high_level_explanation: This expression measures, for a fixed cluster q at hierarchy depth t, the change in cost when refining the partition from level t to level t+1. The first term is the average (over r_{t+1}) of pairwise costs c(x_i, T(x_j)) computed within the current cluster X_q^{(t)}, interpreted as the coarse-scale distortion projected to the next scale. The second term sums the same cost but restricted to each of the r_{t+1} refined child sub-clusters at depth t+1, representing the finer-scale distortion. Their difference is used to quantify how much the refinement decreases the cost within that cluster.

notations.r_{t+1}: Rank parameter at refinement step t+1 (from the rank-schedule)
notations.\\mathsf{X}_{q}^{(t)}: Indices of points in the q-th co-cluster at hierarchy depth t
notations.\\mathsf{X}_{q \\rho_t + z}^{(t+1)}: Indices of points in the z-th refined child block corresponding to parent cluster q at depth t+1
notations.c: Pairwise cost function (assumed strictly convex and Lipschitz in the paper's setup)
notations.T: Transport map (Monge map) applied to source points
notations.\\rho_t: Number of co-clusters (size of the partition) at hierarchy depth t
notations.q: Index of a co-cluster at depth t
notations.z: Index of a refined child block at depth t+1; ranges from 1 to r_{t+1}

formulas.label: <<FORMULA_0443>>
formulas.high_level_explanation: These equations define barycenters (empirical means) for a refined co-cluster at hierarchy level t+1. Specifically, xÃÑ^(t) is the average of the source vectors in the refined block, and yÃÑ^(t) is the average of their transported images under T, both normalized by the block size s_{t+1}. These centroids are used to apply Jensen's inequality, replacing averages of the cost over many pairs by the cost evaluated at the averaged representatives.

notations.\\bar{\\mathbf{x}}^{(t)}: Barycenter (average) of the vectors in the refined block at depth t
notations.\\bar{\\mathbf{y}}^{(t)}: Barycenter (average) of transported vectors T(\mathbf{x}_i) from the same refined block at depth t
notations.\\mathsf{X}_{q \\rho_t + z}^{(t+1)}: The z-th refined subset (block) of the q-th co-cluster at hierarchy depth t+1
notations.T(\\mathbf{x}_{i}): Image of \mathbf{x}_i under the Monge transport map T
notations.q: Index of the parent co-cluster at depth t
notations.\\rho_t: Number of co-clusters (blocks) at hierarchy depth t
notations.z: Local refinement index within the parent co-cluster (ranges over the r_{t+1} children)

formulas.label: <<FORMULA_0445>>
formulas.high_level_explanation: The expression rewrites the total within-subcluster cost at refinement level t+1 as s_{t+1}^2 times an average over each refined block and then upper-bounds it using Jensen's inequality for the convex cost c. Summing over the r_{t+1} refined blocks yields an upper bound of s_{t+1}^2 r_{t+1} times the cost evaluated at the barycenters (centroids) of the points and their images under T within each block. Intuitively, the average pairwise cost within a block is no larger than the cost at the block‚Äôs barycenters when c is convex.

notations.\\mathsf{X}_{q \\rho_t + z}^{(t+1)}: Refined subset of points at depth t+1 indexed by q \rho_t + z (the exact construction is NOT MENTIONED).
notations.\\mathsf{X}_{q\\rho_t + z}^{(t+1)}: Same refined subset as above (identical object; different spacing in LaTeX).
notations.c: Cost function; assumed strictly convex and Lipschitz in the context.
notations.T: Transport map (Monge map) sending source points to target space.
notations.r_{t+1}: Rank/refinement parameter at step t+1 (from the rank-schedule).
notations.\\bar{\\mathbf{x}}^{(t)}: Barycenter (mean) of the points in \mathsf{X}_{q \rho_t + z}^{(t+1)}.
notations.\\bar{\\mathbf{y}}^{(t)}: Barycenter (mean) of the transported points T(\mathbf{x}) for \mathbf{x} in \mathsf{X}_{q \rho_t + z}^{(t+1)}.
notations.\\mathbf{x}_i: A point from the subset \mathsf{X}_{q \rho_t + z}^{(t+1)}.
notations.\\mathbf{x}_j: A point from the subset \mathsf{X}_{q \rho_t + z}^{(t+1)}.
notations.q: Index of a co-cluster at level t.

formulas.label: <<FORMULA_0446>>
formulas.high_level_explanation: This chain of inequalities and equalities upper-bounds a within-cluster cost difference arising during a refinement step in a hierarchical optimal transport procedure. It starts from the average pairwise cost over a coarse cluster and subtracts a Jensen-bound term involving the barycenters of a finer partition, then rewrites the result using cluster sizes to express it as an average of centered costs. The final form shows the bound as the average, over all pairs in the coarse cluster, of the deviation of their cost from the cost at the barycentric pair. This representation prepares the expression to be further controlled using Lipschitz properties and cluster diameters.

notations.r_{t+1}: Refinement factor (number of sub-clusters produced from each cluster) from level t to t+1 in the rank-schedule
notations.\\mathsf{X}_{q}^{(t)}: The q-th subset (cluster) of source points at hierarchy level t
notations.T: Transport map (Monge map) sending source points to the target space
notations.c: Pairwise cost function (assumed strictly convex and Lipschitz)
notations.s_{t+1}: Cardinality (size) of each refined subset \mathsf{X}_{q \rho_t + z}^{(t+1)} at level t+1
notations.\\bar{\\mathbf{x}}^{(t)}: Barycenter (mean) of a refined subset \mathsf{X}_{q \rho_t + z}^{(t+1)}
notations.\\bar{\\mathbf{y}}^{(t)}: Barycenter (mean) of the mapped refined subset T(\mathsf{X}_{q \rho_t + z}^{(t+1)})
notations.\\rho_t: Number of clusters (co-clusters) at hierarchy level t

formulas.label: <<FORMULA_0447>>
formulas.high_level_explanation: This expression defines a diameter-like quantity for the co-cluster Œì_{t,q} as the minimal distance between any two paired points of the form (x_i, T(x_j)) and (x_k, T(x_l)), where all x‚Äôs come from the same block X_q^{(t)}. It constructs pairs from the set X_q^{(t)} and its image under the transport map T, and takes the smallest norm of their difference in the product space. Note that, unlike the standard notion of diameter (which uses a maximum), this definition uses a minimum, yielding a measure of the tightest separation within the paired set.

notations.\\Gamma_{t,q}: q-th co-cluster at hierarchy depth t
notations.\\mathsf{X}_q^{(t)}: q-th subset (block) of the source partition at depth t
notations.T(\\mathsf{X}_q^{(t)}): image of \mathsf{X}_q^{(t)} under the transport map T
notations.T(\\mathbf{x}_j): image of \mathbf{x}_j under the transport map T
notations.T(\\mathbf{x}_l): image of \mathbf{x}_l under the transport map T

formulas.label: <<FORMULA_0452>>
formulas.high_level_explanation: This inequality upper-bounds the per-cluster cost difference during one refinement step by the product of a Lipschitz constant of the cost function and an average dispersion term. Specifically, it sums the distances in the joint (x, T(x)) space between each pair (x_i, T(x_j)) in the cluster and the corresponding barycentric pair, scaled by 1/r_{t+1}. Intuitively, smoother costs (small sup-norm of the gradient) and tighter clusters (small deviations from the barycenter) yield smaller cost changes across refinement.

notations.r_{t+1}: Next-step rank parameter in the rank-schedule (the refinement factor at depth t+1)
notations.\\mathsf{X}_{q}^{(t)}: The q-th cluster (subset) of the source partition at hierarchy depth t
notations.\\mathbf{x}_i: A source sample belonging to the cluster \mathsf{X}_{q}^{(t)} (indexed by i)
notations.\\mathbf{x}_j: A source sample belonging to the cluster \mathsf{X}_{q}^{(t)} (indexed by j)
notations.\\lVert \\nabla c \\rVert_{\\infty}: Supremum norm of the gradient of the cost function c (a global Lipschitz constant for c)
notations.T(\\mathbf{x}_j): Image of \mathbf{x}_j under the transport (Monge) map T
notations.\\bar{\\mathbf{x}}^{(t)}: Barycenter (mean) of the relevant refined subset of source points associated with the cluster at depth t
notations.\\bar{\\mathbf{y}}^{(t)}: Barycenter (mean) of the transported points T(x) over the same refined subset

formulas.label: <<FORMULA_0453>>
formulas.high_level_explanation: This chain of bounds upper-bounds a per-cluster deviation term by replacing each cost difference with a Lipschitz bound proportional to the cluster diameter. The double sum over points in the same cluster contributes a factor equal to the number of ordered pairs, and division by r_{t+1} averages over the refinements at the next level. The final equalities count pairs via |X_q^{(t)}|^2 and then use balanced partitioning to substitute |X_q^{(t)}| = n/\rho_t, yielding a bound proportional to (n^2/\rho_t^2) times the diameter. Overall, it shows the term scales with the Lipschitz constant of c and the cluster diameter.

notations.r_{t+1}: Refinement factor at level t+1 (number of child clusters per parent cluster)
notations.\\mathsf{X}_{q}^{(t)}: The q-th subset of source points at scale t
notations.|\\mathsf{X}_{q}^{(t)}|^{2}: Square of the size of the cluster \mathsf{X}_{q}^{(t)}
notations.\\Gamma_{t,q}: The q-th co-cluster at scale t associated with \mathsf{X}_{q}^{(t)} (paired with T(\mathsf{X}_{q}^{(t)}))
notations.\\mathrm{diam}\\bigl( \\Gamma_{t,q}\\big: Diameter of the co-cluster \Gamma_{t,q} as defined earlier in the text
notations.\\rho_t: Number of clusters at scale t
notations.\\nabla c: Gradient of the cost function c
notations.\\lVert \\nabla c \\rVert_{\\infty}: Supremum norm of the gradient of c (a global Lipschitz bound)

formulas.label: <<FORMULA_0454>>
formulas.high_level_explanation: This line aggregates the per-cluster bounds and simplifies constants, yielding a clean expression that depends only on the cost function‚Äôs Lipschitz constant and the average cluster diameter at level t. Using that each level‚Äët block is refined into r_{t+1} children (so œÅ_{t+1} = r_{t+1} œÅ_t), the factors in n, œÅ, and r cancel. The resulting bound is the sup norm of the gradient of the cost multiplied by the average diameter of the co-clusters at level t. It shows the overall cost difference after refinement is controlled by within-cluster diameters at the current scale.

notations.\\rho_{t+1}: Number of co-clusters at refinement level t+1
notations.n: Number of samples per marginal (total pairs are n^2)
notations.r_{t+1}: Per-cluster refinement factor from level t to t+1 (number of children of each level‚Äët block)
notations.\\lVert \\nabla c \\rVert_{\\infty}: Uniform bound (sup norm) of the gradient of the cost function c; the Lipschitz constant of c
notations.\\rho_t: Number of co-clusters at refinement level t
notations.q: Index of the co-cluster at level t
notations.\\Gamma_{t,q}: The q-th co-cluster at level t (associated with \mathsf{X}^{(t)}_q and its image under T)
notations.\\mathrm{diam}\\bigl( \\Gamma_{t,q}\\big: Diameter of the co-cluster \Gamma_{t,q}, as defined in the text (size of \mathsf{X}^{(t)}_q \cup T(\mathsf{X}^{(t)}_q))

formulas.label: <<FORMULA_0457>>
formulas.high_level_explanation: This inequality shows that a previously introduced quantity is upper-bounded by a sum whose terms cancel exactly and therefore the bound equals zero. Using the equal-size partition identities |X_q^{(t)}| = n/œÅ_t and |X_q^{(t-1)}| = n/œÅ_{t+1}, the expression inside the absolute value becomes Œ≥[(n/œÅ_t)^2/r_{t+1} ‚àí r_{t+1}(n/œÅ_{t+1})^2], which vanishes under the refinement relation between levels. Consequently, each summand is zero and the entire sum evaluates to zero.

notations.q: Index over blocks at level t (runs from 1 to \rho_t)
notations.r_{t+1}: Rank/refinement factor at level t+1 (number of sub-blocks per coarse block)
notations.\\mathsf{X}_{q}^{(t)}: q-th block of the level t partition of the source set
notations.\\mathsf{X}_{q}^{(t - 1)}: q-th block of the level t‚àí1 partition of the source set

formulas.label: <<FORMULA_0460>>
formulas.formula:
& \int_{\mathsf{X} \times \mathsf{Y}} \lVert T_{\theta}(x) - y \rVert_{2}^{p} (\mathrm{id} \times T)_{\sharp} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \mu_{i} \delta_{x_{i}} \mathrm{d} x \mathrm{d} y = \int_{\mathsf{X} \times \mathsf{Y}} \lVert T_{\theta}(x) - y \rVert_{2}^{p} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \mu_{i} (\mathrm{id} \times T)_{\sharp} \delta_{x_{i}} \mathrm{d}x \mathrm{d}y  \\
    &= \sum_{i=1}^{n} \mu_{i} \int_{\mathsf{X} / \mathsf{Y}} \lVert T_{\theta}(x) - y \rVert_{2}^{p} \delta_{(x_{i}, T(x_{i}))} \mathrm{d}y \mathrm{d}x = \sum_{i=1}^{n} \mu_{i} \lVert T_{\theta}(x_{i}) - T(x_{i}) \rVert_{2}^{p} \, ,
formulas.high_level_explanation: The expression shows that integrating the p-th power of the Euclidean discrepancy between T_theta(x) and y over the product space with respect to the pushforward of a discrete source measure equals a simple weighted sum over samples. By linearity of the pushforward and of the integral, and by evaluating against Dirac measures, the integral reduces to masses placed on the graph of T. Consequently, the loss becomes the weighted sum of pointwise p-th power errors between the learned map T_theta and the Monge map T at the data points.

notations.x_{i}: i-th data point in the source space
notations.T_{\\theta}: neural network map parameterized by theta
notations.\\mathrm{id}: identity map on the source space
notations.(\\mathrm{id} \\times T)_{\\sharp}: pushforward operator induced by the map x ‚Ü¶ (x, T(x))
notations.\\mu_{i}: weight of the source measure at x_i
notations.\\delta_{(x_{i}, T(x_{i}))}: Dirac measure at the pair (x_i, T(x_i))

formulas.label: <<FORMULA_0520>>
formulas.high_level_explanation: The expression defines the multiscale partition hierarchies on the metric measure spaces X and Y. For each scale j from 0 to J, Œì_j(X) (respectively Œì_j(Y)) is the partition at that scale, consisting of K_j(X) (resp. K_j(Y)) clusters C_{j,k}(X) (resp. C_{j,k}(Y)). The collections Œì(ùîõ) and Œì(ùîú) gather these partitions over all scales, forming the hierarchical (tree-like) structure used later for coarsening and optimal transport.

notations.J: maximum scale index in the multiscale hierarchy
notations.\\Gamma({\\mathsf{X}}): full multiscale family of partitions on X across scales 0..J
notations.\\Gamma_j(\\mathsf{X}): partition of X at scale j (collection of cells C_{j,k}(\mathsf{X}))
notations.C_{j,k}(\\mathsf{X}): k-th cluster (cell) of the scale-j partition of X
notations.K_j(\\mathsf{X}): number of clusters in the scale-j partition of X
notations.\\Gamma({\\mathsf{Y}}): full multiscale family of partitions on Y across scales 0..J
notations.\\Gamma_j(\\mathsf{Y}): partition of Y at scale j (collection of cells C_{j,k}(\mathsf{Y}))
notations.C_{j,k}(\\mathsf{Y}): k-th cluster (cell) of the scale-j partition of Y
notations.K_j(\\mathsf{Y}): number of clusters in the scale-j partition of Y

formulas.label: <<FORMULA_0539>>
formulas.high_level_explanation: This formula defines a coarsened cost at scale j between the cluster centers x_{j,k} and y_{j,k'} as the average of the base cost c(x, y) over all pairs of points taken from the corresponding clusters. It aggregates fine-scale pointwise costs into a single representative value for the pair of clusters. This provides a local average cost used for multiscale optimal transport computations on the coarsened spaces.

notations.\\mathsf{c}_j: Coarsened cost function at scale j defined via local averaging over cluster pairs
notations.x_{j,k}: Center of the cluster C_{j,k}(\mathsf{X}) at scale j in \mathsf{X}
notations.y_{j, k'}: Center of the cluster C_{j,k'}(\mathsf{Y}) at scale j in \mathsf{Y}
notations.C_{j,k}(\\mathsf{X}): k-th cluster at scale j in the multiscale partition of \mathsf{X}
notations.C_{j,k'}(\\mathsf{Y}): k'-th cluster at scale j in the multiscale partition of \mathsf{Y}
notations.\\mathsf{c}(x,y): Original pointwise cost function between a point x in \mathsf{X} and a point y in \mathsf{Y}
notations.| C_{j,k}(\\mathsf{X}) |: Cardinality (number of points) of the cluster C_{j,k}(\mathsf{X})
notations.| C_{j,k'}(\\mathsf{Y}) |: Cardinality (number of points) of the cluster C_{j,k'}(\mathsf{Y})
notations.\\mathsf{X}: Discrete metric measure space serving as the source domain
notations.\\mathsf{Y}: Discrete metric measure space serving as the target domain
notations.x: A point in the cluster C_{j,k}(\mathsf{X})
notations.y: A point in the cluster C_{j,k'}(\mathsf{Y})
notations.j: Scale index in the multiscale partition hierarchy
notations.k: Index of a cluster in \mathsf{X} at scale j
notations.k': Index of a cluster in \mathsf{Y} at scale j

formulas.label: <<FORMULA_0540>>
formulas.high_level_explanation: This formula defines a coarsened cost c_j at scale j between the cluster centers x_{j,k} and y_{j,k'}. It computes a weighted average of the base cost c(x, y) over all point pairs drawn from the corresponding clusters, where the weights come from the previous scale's optimal transport coupling evaluated at the parent cells of x and y. The denominator normalizes by the aggregate weight (here written as a product over the same weights), so the resulting value reflects a local, previous-scale-informed cost between the clusters.

notations.\\mathsf{c}_j: Coarsened cost function at scale j between clusters k in X and k' in Y
notations.x_{j,k}: Center of cluster C_{j,k}(\mathsf{X}) at scale j
notations.y_{j, k'}: Center of cluster C_{j,k'}(\mathsf{Y}) at scale j
notations.C_{j,k}(\\mathsf{X}): Cluster (cell) with index k at scale j in the multiscale partition of \mathsf{X}
notations.C_{j,k'}(\\mathsf{Y}): Cluster (cell) with index k' at scale j in the multiscale partition of \mathsf{Y}
notations.\\pi_{j-1}^\\star: Optimal (or approximately optimal) OT coupling at scale j‚àí1
notations.x_{j-1, k_1}: Parent cluster center in \mathsf{X} at scale j‚àí1 corresponding (via the tree) to x \in C_{j,k}(\mathsf{X})
notations.y_{j-1, k_1'}: Parent cluster center in \mathsf{Y} at scale j‚àí1 corresponding (via the tree) to y \in C_{j,k'}(\mathsf{Y})
notations.j: Scale index in the multiscale partition hierarchy
notations.k: Cluster index in \mathsf{X} at scale j
notations.k': Cluster index in \mathsf{Y} at scale j
notations.k_1: Parent cluster index in \mathsf{X} at scale j‚àí1 determined by the tree structure
notations.k_1': Parent cluster index in \mathsf{Y} at scale j‚àí1 determined by the tree structure

formulas.label: <<FORMULA_0545>>
formulas.high_level_explanation: This expression defines the optimal transport coupling at scale j as the plan that minimizes a cost functional over all couplings with marginals mu_j and nu_j. The cost functional is computed as a product, over all cluster-pair indices at scale j, of the pairwise ground cost c(x_{j,k}, y_{j,k'}) multiplied by the plan entry pi_j(x_{j,k}, y_{j,k'}). The indices span the clusters in the multiscale partitions of the source and target spaces, and x_{j,k}, y_{j,k'} are the corresponding cluster centers.

notations.\\pi_j^\\star: Optimal transport coupling (plan) at scale j
notations.\\pi: A candidate coupling (transport plan) between \mu_j and \nu_j
notations.\\Pi( \\mu_j, \\nu_j): Set of couplings with marginals \mu_j and \nu_j at scale j
notations.\\mu_j: Measure on \mathsf{X} at scale j (coarse-grained source measure)
notations.\\nu_j: Measure on \mathsf{Y} at scale j (coarse-grained target measure)
notations.\\mathrm{cost}( \\pi_j ): Objective functional evaluated on the coupling \pi_j at scale j
notations.[K_j(\\mathsf{X})]: Index set of clusters in \mathsf{X} at scale j
notations.[K_j(\\mathsf{Y})]: Index set of clusters in \mathsf{Y} at scale j
notations.K_j(\\mathsf{X}): Number of clusters in \mathsf{X} at scale j
notations.K_j(\\mathsf{Y}): Number of clusters in \mathsf{Y} at scale j
notations.x_{j,k}: Center (representative) of cluster k in \mathsf{X} at scale j
notations.y_{j,k'}: Center (representative) of cluster k' in \mathsf{Y} at scale j
notations.c( x_{j,k}, y_{j,k'} ): Pairwise ground cost between centers x_{j,k} and y_{j,k'} at scale j
notations.\\pi_j ( x_{j,k}, y_{j,k'} ): Mass assigned by the coupling \pi_j to the pair (x_{j,k}, y_{j,k'})
